sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Related articles

- Internationalization

This article describes how to set up a Wikipedia:Bengali language environment. It does not cover setting up Bengali/Bangla input on the console.

sections.title: Fonts
sections.content:
- ttf-freebanglafontAUR - Font for Bangla
- Avro Unicode Fonts & Lipighor free fonts - Install following Fonts#Manual installation

sections.title: Locale
sections.content:
Open /etc/locale.gen with your favorite text editor. And then uncomment bn_BD.UTF-8 UTF-8 or bn_IN.UTF-8 UTF-8:

```
/etc/locale.gen
```

```
...
#bi_VU UTF-8
bn_BD UTF-8
#bn_IN UTF-8
...
```

and then run locale-gen. For more information please read this article

sections.title: Input methods
sections.content:
There are multiple open source input method engines available:

- Avro supports phonetic input for Bangla in IBus via ibus-avro-gitAUR.
- OpenBangla Keyboard supports Bangla phonetic (Avro phonetic), Probhat, Munir Optima layout for Bangla in IBus via openbangla-keyboardAUR.
- ibus-m17nAUR provider for Unijoy, Inscript, Probhat, Disha and ITRANS

See IBus to set up the engines above.

See also Input method for a list of available input-method frameworks.

sections.title: Broken fonts in Firefox
sections.content: Some applications (like Firefox) and Desktop Environments will use ttf-font (ttf-dejavu, ttf-liberation, ttf-bitstream-vera, ttf-droid, gnu-free-fonts, noto-fonts, ttf-croscore, ttf-ibm-plex) by default. The gnu-free-fonts do not have full support for Bengali characters alignment. Consider using noto-fonts over ttf-dejavu or gnu-free-fonts as a ttf-font source.

sections.title: No IBus Support in GNOME
sections.content: The IBus preferences does not work with GNOME. Make sure to enable Avro/OpenBangla from gnome-control-center.
